UnitType.Backstory:
It was late autumn. In the west little had changed. Amarian farmers harvested their crops and celebrated their queen without concern. Even the queen spared little thought for the expedition she sent east, or the hero and oracle whose fate she had entwined.
Until the night the resurrection failed, when even Queen Procipinee's dreams were full of shadows and tears. When Tarth hunters huddled close to their fires and Ironeer sentrys saw shapes moving in the darkness. When those near death were dragged under by vengeful spirits.
Many arose that night, the dead unwilling or unable to pass through that haunted field to their rest. Who linger now in eternal pain and see everyone as the dark shapes that torment them. But the most tragic of these are the Banshee, sweet in life even the torments of demons hasn't made them hateful. They merely cry, and it is the echoes of this soul in agony that destroys any that would hear it.

These are the thousand who cannot die, unholy survivors of a pact made by Amhah in the time before this one. Butchermen believe, however, that if they kill another, their victims will become trapped - undead, undying, doomed to wander the world forever - in their place, and they can pass on to death.

UnitType.Quote: You are a new immortal, a child who has only known daylight. In time mountains will wear down, gods will fall and the sun will fade away.
UnitType.Backstory: Among the soldiers of Amhah's undead army, these are the most powerful. In the time before this one, they were men of great honor - soldiers entrusted with guarding the temple of the Five, at Atalandra. At Amhah's command, it was they who led the unfortunates chosen for sacrifice to the altar - and it was they who were then slaughtered themselves on the fields of Gaer Blodwyn by the Emperor Curgen, before rising again by his command of necromancy, doomed to wander the world for all their days.

UnitType.Quote: I am the sacrifice, the price paid to appease the Titans. I will not bear this burden alone.
UnitType.Backstory: In the time before this one, these were holy men and women, acolytes of the Five, consecrated body, mind, and soul to the service of the Elemental Lords of Old. When Amhah revealed his plan to offer up sacrifice to Curgen, in an attempt to save the people of Atalandra, these brave souls volunteered their own lives in order to spare others. They fell first to Amhah's blade - in vain, as it turns out, for Curgen's messenger - the butcher Magnar I - declared Amhah's offering inadequate' to the glory of his master.

UnitType.Quote: This world is a ruined shadow of its former self, its inhabitants should be the same.
UnitType.Backstory:
Agonis forfeit his relations with his family, his friends (such as they were) and humanity to seek eternity. He gathered the small violet flowers that grew at the edge of the Pit of Lost Voices, he studied the writings of the titans and others to whom centuries were as days, he sipped Naja venom and spent days freezing and alone on the Northern Wastes. He spoke to demons and elementals whose forms were only a vessel for their eternal will.
He tested his spells and potions on countless animals, without success. But perhaps they were too far from men, a meager rabbit could not ascend to immortality. So he opened a small infirmary and invited the infirm and dying into his care. Though they all died tortured and suffering, he was giving them the chance to cheat death entirely. But they weren't strong enough to accept the gift, you cannot limp across the threshold to godhood.
So Agonis began testing on healthy subjects. They lay within an oubliette he had devised, their horrified screams echoing through the tunnels where he did his research, long past the point where their voices were recognizable as human. But still they died.
One night Agonis looked at his reflection and didn't recognize the old man he had become. His hair was thin and grey, his face pale and spotted with age. His eyes were clouded and etched with worry. His life was past him, and he had no answers through his endless trials.
Though screams still echoed through his tunnels Agonis prepared for one last ritual. He drank the Abois wine, called out the names of spirits that may be myth and spilled out his life out that he may stand without heart or blood or flesh. And he died as his experiments had.
As Agonis lay dead the world changed. A cataclysm created oceans and destroyed continents, mountains were ground to dust and the power of Elemental was bound into crystalline prisons. But this was nothing to Agonis, he had found eternity and it was empty.
Until the world broke again, but this time it was the world of the dead that was split. And Agonis awoke from his empty dream and rose. No longer flesh, no longer alive, and forever tortured. But he was at last immortal.

The people of Anniellum screamed as the sky exploded and fire, lava and ash rained down on them. They screamed as they fled burning homes, as they saw the horror of charred corpses before them. They screamed as Delin, the Pyre of Man, loomed over them, as he summoned new waves of flame down on the city, and as it consumed their flesh.
Their screams continue as they lumber out of the ruins of Anniellum, burning spirits held together by pain, fire and cruel hunger.

The Shadowed Sepulcher started as a low, swampy field around a sharp edged stone nearly the size of a wagon. Nothing grew in the field and the ground was too soft to support building so the people of Millis Mor made it into their graveyard. Animals avoid the area and it was quiet, somber and unsettling. The land was so soft that grave markers disappeared into the ground within a few years of being placed.
Some complained that the dismal field is no place for the honored dead. But more valuable land was claimed for new farms, homes or markets in the growing village. Because the grave markers disappeared into the ground old sections of the field would open up for a new generation of memories, tears and bodies.
Until that autumn night when the resurrection failed. Many speculated that only those that were troubled or cruel in life rose. But it was the lingering spirits of demons that animated them. And that great twisted stone at the center of the Shadowed Sepulcher was a death shard, a prison of corrupted magic and whispering demons. The demons called to the dead of Millis Mor, to the dead of villages past that had been built at that site, and those that had been sacrificed there long ago when the site was a temple to the cult of a hundred eyes.
And the dead poured out of the soft ground. Together they swept into Millis Mor, captured every citizen and dragged them back to the Shadowed Sepulcher and buried them alive and screaming in the soft ground.
Now the village lies empty and inviting. There is no sign or trouble, only empty buildings and overgrown fields that could be repaired with little work. And any who resettled the village would find it a good home for most of the year. Until that autumn night came again, and the demons called for the dead to bring their sacrifice. In the morning the village would be empty again, and another generation of bodies would be added to the Shadowed Sepulcher.
